daysrsquo notice.Again, this may risk good staff relations and given that employers and employees will likely be unfamiliar in dealing with a health crisis of this magnitude, it will be good practice title: coronavirus-80-infection-rate-not-realistic-estimate-says-top-infection-scientist
story: Professor Hugh Pennington, emeritus professor of bacteriology at Aberdeen University, said the predictions were based on a scenario of widespread human-to-human transmission where "we just let the virus run" without any attempt to contain it.The Scottish Government said on Monday that a "reasonable worst case scenario" could see  to % of the population contract the strain, known a Covid-.: Routine ops could be cancelled in peak outbreakProf Pennington said: "Its not a realistic estimate."The worst case scenario is definitely the worst case scenario: it means that everything that could go wrong does go wrong, with absolutely no containment measures in place."The mathematical models have shown that the spread of the virus will be very severely restrictedwe lock up people who have been in contact with it - self-isolation so to speak - or we take all the patients whove definitely got symptoms and we put them in hospital, because thats another form of isolation, in effect."The people who weve really got to worry about are healthcare workers which has always been a problem, because the super spreaders are the ones who are coughing and spluttering and theyre the ones most likely to end up in hospital."The Scottish Government says a peak outbreak could see % of Scotlands . million population infected, with % of this group requiring hospitalisation - around , people.The estimate is in line with World Health Organisation data which analysed more than , cases in China and found that % of patients developed mild symptoms such as a cough, fever or runny nose, but around % became critically ill with complications such as respiratory failure, septic shock, or organ failure.The risk was particularly high among older people, especially over s, and in patients with diabetes, high blood pressure, and heart or lung conditions.Alarmingly, mortality among the critically ill has also been running at more than %, according to the WHO.: Coronavirus could be tackled using emergency lawsIn a "worst-case scenario" Scotland where .m become infected, that would translate to , critically ill and more than , dead.To put that into context, NHS Scotland has only , acute hospital beds and the worst winter flu season in recent years claimed around , lives across the whole of the UK.In  - the most recent year for which data is available - a total of , people died in Scotland from all forms of cancer.However, scrutiny of the latest figures for Hubei, the Chinese province where the virus first originated in December, shows that there have been , confirmed cases in a population of just over m - an incidence rate of .%.In China as a whole, there are now , confirmed cases of Covid- in a population of over . billion - equivalent to six per , people - while in Italy, which has the third highest prevalence of the virus in the world, there are three cases for every , people.Professor Rowland Kao, chair of veterinary epidemiology and data science at University of Edinburghrsquos Roslin Institute, said: "I think what it comes down to is that when we talk about worst case scenarios, the implication is when you do nothing to stop it."Now of course in Hubei theyve done everything they can to stop it. Probably more than anyone  in the world."Politically, China is obviously much better placed to put up very stringent controls. So the number they have is partially due to that response.": Scotland facing chronic shortage of consultantsA WHO report published on Friday February  credited Chinas "aggressive response" for curtailing the spread of the virus.The number of new cases peaked in early February and has been slowing ever since, while transmission has escalated in the rest of the world.The WHO report said China had "rolled out perhaps the most ambitious, agile, and aggressive disease containment effort in history", and in doing so "has changed the course of a rapidly escalating and deadly epidemic.Interventions included the lockdown of Wuhan - the city at the centre of the outbreak - and nearby cities in Hubei province.Elsewhere in China people voluntarily quarantined themselves with their compliance monitored by appointed neighbourhood leaders.Two new dedicated hospitals were built in Wuhan within a week - with many of the beds now lying empty - and aggressive "social distancing" measures were implemented, such as cancelling sporting fixtures, closing theatres and cinemas, and extending the Chinese New Year school holidays.WHO scientists who visited hospitals, railway stations, food markets, and other public spaces described "a sense of responsibility and collective action...therersquos war footing to get things done.In Western democracies, such stringent controls and cooperation are harder to imagine, but the UK governments battle plan includes potential measures such as school closures, putting the Army on standby to help fill gaps in emergency services arising from an outbreak, giving health boards the power to detain people with the virus and stop them from travelling, or forcing those suspected of having the virus to be tested and quarantined under court order.Professor Kao believes the -% figure for peak outbreak in the UK has probably been extrapolated using something called the "basic reproduction number", a theoretical model used by scientists to predict the limits of an outbreak.He added: "Its a funny thing because you want to motivate people enough to listen, but you dont want to scare them."You want them to do the things that are sensible. If people dont take it seriously, theyre pretty much going to go about their daily business."That includes people who are a little bit sick still going to work, or still sending their kids to school."So what youre trying to do is say look,we actually do nothing, these are the kinds of numbers we could end up with."A Scottish Government spokesmansaid: ldquoA lsquoreasonable worst case scenariorsquo would be that -% of the population might become infected. But in this case, a large proportion of the infected population are likely to show no symptoms.However, as more data becomes available from around the world this will allow modellers to give us increasingly accurate estimates."

title: new-minister-elderly-demanded-stop-scots-sleepwalking-pension-poverty
story: While over-s in Scotland are anticipating they will need an annual pension income of pound, - that is % higher than the average income of a full time UK employee and more than double todayrsquos average of pound,.A report published by lenders organisation, the Equity Release Council and financial advisers Keys calls for a specialist minister for the elderly as the "ambitious" pension income expectation is leaving a potential shortfall of pound, a year.There are now concerns that people are simply sleepwalking into pension poverty, relying on the state pension to top up whatever savings they do manage.:Analysis -The pension crisis could be worse for NHS than BrexitAnd the report says a new UK government minister could ensure "broader social and financial issues" are recognised and co-ordinated across all government departments to over come "tunnel vision in retirement planning".They say that multiple pressures, from rising living costs to mortgage commitments, are not only stling savings, but eroding pension pots as one in sixplan to draw on their pension savings early.The research comes as experts fear retirement planning is not front of mind for the average Brit, even though automatic pension enrolment came into full effect in February  Three in five British adultsare now saving for the future, yet one-fth, totalling almost eight million people, believe they will never be able to retire.David Burrowes, chairman of the Equity Release Council, said: ldquoWith the UKrsquos population ageing rapidly, the scale of this issue is only set to become greater. An increasing number of consumers must make their pensions savings last over longer retirements with property wealth fast emerging as a viable solution to help meet this funding challenge.ldquoOur report emphasises the pension pressures faced by many across the UK and calls for property wealth to be better considered and integrated into the advice process. A single-product solution to retirement planning is no longer fit for purpose. We must break down the silos that create tunnel vision when it comes to later le financial planning.: Women business leaders in Scotland face pensions time bombThe report says shows that paying off a mortgage often competes with retirement savings to be older homeownersrsquo biggest financial priority ndash stling pension contributions and increasing the likelihood of people being ldquoasset-rich, cash-poor in later le.Just over one in threehomeowners who have increased their pension savings in the last year have been able to do so as theyrsquore no longer paying off their mortgage.Among those who still have a mortgage, almost halfreport that paying off their mortgage has, or is likely to, limit their pension savings potential.The report that the pensions reality gap among homeowners aged + comes at a time when pension income growth has stalled, increasing by just pound a week over the last decade, and savings pressures are escalating across the UK, which is already home to western Europersquos largest increase in pensioner poverty since .The groups said the Financial Conduct Authority should work to ensure consumers are able to consider the full range of available pension products based on their current and future needs, whatever their entry point to retirement planning conversations.It also says a cross-party later le commission should be established to help meet the long-term needs of people in later le.A report survey shows that across the UK, the challenges of rising living costs , prioritising mortgage repayments over pension savingssupporting financial dependentsand earning less money so unable to afford to save moreare all cited as reasons why homeowners over- are unable to increase their pensions savings.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Nicola Sturgeon must defend women   s rights or lose the next election
story: The police were recording as ldquohate incidents anyone who ldquomisgendered a trans person ndash in other words referred to their biological, natal sex.My successor as Rector of Edinburgh University, Labour feminist Ann Henderson, was being hounded by trans activists for refusing to state that trans women are biologically female. Edinburgh University, astonishingly, failed to support her.The gay tennis icon Martina Navratilova was expelled from the LGBT group, Athlete Ally, for saying that people with male physiques should not complete in womenrsquos sport.Cultural and health bodies, and even the Scottish Government, were ceasing to use the very word ldquowoman in case it offended male-bodied transwomen. Bizarre substitutes like ldquowomxn, ldquomenstruators and ldquociswomen were being deployed in the cause of inclusivity.Well, times change. This issue is now out in the open. More and more women are speaking out against the undermining of sex-based rights.Even the ultra-wokeis permitting columns from feminists like Suzanne Moore calling for an end to the ldquono ing of gender-critical academics like Professor Selina Todd and Dr Kathleen Stock. They have been labelled as ldquoTerfs by trans zealots.Last week, the UK Government called a halt to self-identication legislation south of the Border. Ministers discovered that children as young as  are being given puberty blockers by gender reassignment clinics. Puberty blockers halt the sexual development of children. They are of the class of drugs once used as chemical castration for sex offenders.Influential figures in the SNP, like the former communications guru, Kevin Pringle, are now urging Nicola Sturgeon to follow the UK Government. But the Scottish Equalities Secretary, Shirley-Anne Somerville, apparently intends to press ahead with legislation to allow self-ID. Mr Pringle is speaking for many in the party who now realise that the growing backlash against Self-ID could threaten the SNPrsquos chances in next yearrsquos Holyrood elections.Yet it seemed glaringly obvious to me two years ago that women would never accept this existential assault on their sexual identity. How could they be expected to accept people with male genitalia and masculine physiques as real women  Why should women be forced to accept male-bodied transwomen in their protected spaces, in changing rooms and toilets Indeed, at first I thought this proposition that transwomen were literally women was just anti-trans scaremongering. Surely activists werenrsquot actually saying that they were biologically female I learned the hard way that this is precisely what they were saying. I was repeatedly accused of hate speech for suggesting that this would mean the removal of human biology from the school curriculum.Political leaders like Patrick Harvie of the Scottish Greens and the former leader of the Liberal Democrats Jo Swinson continue to insist that people with penises can be and are actually female. Labourrsquos Shadow Equalities Secretary, Dawn Butler, said last month that ldquobabies are born without a sex. This is pure flat earthism.Shamefully, leading feminists like Germaine Greer have been ldquocancelled for objecting to extreme transgenderism as misogyny. That it demeans and invalidates women.How could someone with a male body possibly experience social reality in the way real women do  Transwomen do not have uteruses, do not menstruate, do not give birth.Trans advocates reply that, well, some women canrsquot give birth and some women donrsquot menstruate. This is ridiculous and offensive sophistry. Asa woman ceases to be a womanshe canrsquot have children.These canards are still re on social media with people arguing that clown fish changing sex, and people born intersex ldquoprovethat there is no fixed biological definition of sex.Humans are of course mammals, not fish. The existence of a minuscule number of people born intersexdoesnrsquot alter the fact that . per cent of humans are born male or female.Humans are a binary species. We are not hermaphrodites. Sexual dferentiation is the basis of human reproduction. That this needs to be said is a shocking reflection on the intellectual integrity of the left. Many supposedly sensible people have been morally coerced into accepting something they know to be untrue. It is deeply worrying.Most SNP politicians know that transgender ideology is nonsense. They keep quiet partly because of fear of Britainrsquos onerous hate speech laws.It has been left to genuinely courageous women like Joan McAlpine MSP and Joanna Cherry, MP, to fight for reason. For doing so they have been the target of astonishing abuse on social media, and from the trans activists embedded in the SNP.Academics like Lucy Hunter Blackburn have bravely challenged the proposal to remove the question on sex from the national census.This has nothing to do with ldquotransgender rights. Trans people are free to identy as anyone they wish. No one is stopping them wearing what they want or loving who they wish. This is not homophobia ..In fact, advocates of Self-ID, like Stonewall, have set back the cause of trans rights by harnessing it to a quasi-religious dogma.Mr Pringle and others in the SNP now realise that the Scottish Government is marching into a minefield by persevering with Self-ID without proper debate. Given the pause in England, it could lead to a transgender Gretna Green.But there is an equitable solution. Of course allow transwomen to identy as female without needless bureaucratic obstacles. But the Government should make clear in the legislation reforming the Gender Recognition Act that this does not mean abolishing the biological definition of sex or infringing womenrsquos sex-based rights under the Equalities Act.Yoursquod think that a feminist like Nicola Sturgeon would regard that as self-evident. Perhaps she does. Butso she needs to say it loud and clear before half the voting population ndash women ndash turn against the SNP.Read more: Super Tuesday will showcase Democrats dismal failure to take on Donald Trump

title: Rosemary Goring  It  39 s time we moved on from obsession with the terrible Tudors
story: Anne Boleyn did not emerge centre stage like Botticellirsquos Venus, but some believe it was here that Henry VIII first caught sight of her. The rest, as they say, is history. Except, in the case of the Tudor dynasty, this is a period thatrsquos never allowed to die. And in Henryrsquos case, as everyone knows, Anne Boleyn was only the second bite on his kebab.The publication of the final part of Hilary Mantelrsquos Thomas Cromwell trilogy, The Mirror  the Light, has been treated asitrsquos breaking news. The antics of the rapacious Henry VIII and his Machiavellian chief minister took place nearly  years ago, yet the airwaves, review and feature pages, and even fashion spreads are dominated by talk of the Tudors. Whether itrsquos their backstabbing ambition, headbands and bodices, or iron-fisted bureaucracy, weto them again and again, like birds to a hollow coconut shell, hoping for another flake.Mantelrsquos work is as thorough and intense an exploration of the political mind as yoursquoll find. That the previous two books in the series won the Booker Prize indicates their artistic merit as well as their accuracy. Those who donrsquot feel Cromwell merits so many pages might be surprised to find themselves hooked. And, although the factual detail is so well-founded the trilogy could become set texts for students, this is the past recast by the authorrsquos imagination. Official, dispassionate, unspun history it is not.Mantelrsquos portrayal of Henryrsquos sleekit, ruthless, tight-lipped consigliere has parallels with people in power today. Those echoes, and the entanglements of a murderous but exquisitely dressed court, are where the perennial fascination with Henryrsquos entourage lies. That his time on the throne was soon to be followed by Elizabeth Irsquos long tenure has ensured that,this era is to your taste, therersquos enough to chew on for a letime. Yet dramatic and richly brocaded as all this is, havenrsquot we now had enough  Isnrsquot it time to look where, and bid the Tudors farewell Historical fiction sounds like a timeless niche, untroubled by tides of fashion. As Mantelrsquos supremacy shows, however, it is as susceptible to fads as everything . There was a time when the Tudors were considered dusty and tired. Mention of Henryrsquos six wives or the Spanish Armada conjured up Jean Plaidy and school lessons: interestingthat was your kind of thing, but hardly thrilling or new.Writers in this genre are in a tricky situation. Publishers want them to be original yet follow the road more travelled, to mine a popular seam but make it their own. If nothing , Mantelrsquos oeuvre is a masterclass in how to go about this. Yet some years ago, before her meteoric rise, it seemed the appetite for Tudor was waning. The German market, a literary agent told me, had overdosed and lost interest in buying the rights to anything further from this era. Then Mantel rekindled the flame to such an extent that today, from Hamburg to Heidelberg, she will be in bookshop windows, kept company on the shelves by best-selling Alison Weir and Philippa Gregory, both of whom have also made Hampton Court their second home.And, just as the pitiless English royals in farthingales and ruffs are enjoying their moment in the sun, so too is anything set during the two world wars, or in Victoriarsquos later years. Like children who ask for the same story every bedtime, it seems that readers love nothing better than retreading old ground before they douse the lights.Most genre novels are looked down on by the literati as second class citizens. That is why Mantelrsquos Booker victories offered such encouragement for others ploughing a similar furrow. Yet having written historical fiction myself, set in the early th-century Borders, I have reservations: not about the calibre or worth of the genre, but about how it ranks with fiction that comes almost entirely from the writerrsquos imagination.As Andrew Marr said of The Mirror  the Light, the ending is never in doubt. The same goes for aspects of all books in which real-le figures play a part. When it comes to plotting, these fixed points become the beads on the rosary between which the narrative is threaded. They might cause problems when interweaving made-up with documented events, but they provide an off-the-peg outline around which to build a story. Writers portraying modern le through invented characters do not have this luxury. All they can rely upon are their powers of invention and the quality of their prose. To my mind, despite the spadework needed when researching previous centuries, that is a much harder act to pull off.With the Tudors dominating the bestseller lists, what astonishes me most is how little of our history fiction has yet covered. In this country alone there is material for libraries of new novels set in the centuries before the Stewarts claimed the throne, and long after the Jacobites retreated to their peaty hovels. The past might well be a foreign country, as L P Hartley wrote, but some areas seem to attract package holiday tours, leaving tumbleweed to roll through the rest.

title: coronavirus-scotland-number-cases-rises-three-overnight
story: It comes just hours after health secretary Jeane Freeman confirmed the number of confirmed cases of the Covid- virus in Scotland had risen to three overnight.She told BBC Radio Scotlandrsquos Good Morning Scotland programme: "I can confirm that overnight we were informed of two more cases. Obviously at this point, Im sure you can appreciate that there isnt more I can say. We will release more information later - so that takes our total number of cases in Scotland to three.":What are the symptoms and how does it spread The sheltered accommodation was locked down after one resident, who had recently travelled to South East Asia, began displaying symptoms on Tuesday afternoon.Chris Milburn, customer services director for site manager Hanover Scotland, said: ldquoYesterday afternoon, a resident at one of our developments in Ayrshire who had recently ed from south-east Asia reported feeling unwell.ldquoBecause the well-being of our residents and staff is our prime concern, our site manager immediately contacted the NHS and the resident was taken to hospital for tests.ldquoWe took the decision at the same time to ask residents to stay in their homes until this morning as a precaution.ldquoWe have been in touch with each resident this morning and advised them that, in line with advice published by NHS Inform, they can carry on as normal.Scottish Health Minister Jeane Freeman confirms two more #coronavirus cases in Scotland on #BBCGMS, bringing the total to three.Listen live # https:t.co bHyVVqUpdates ## https:t.co cWmFQGvz pic TACKOSdToMs Freeman added: "There are a number of steps that need to go through with the patients concerned and other matters before we can release any level of information, partly its about patient confidentiality, partly its about making sure that we get the right clinical responses to cases."So later in the day, we will be able to let you and others know, but at this point all I can confirm is that we have two more cases, bringing the total to three."As of Tuesday afternoon,  tests had been carried out for the condition.The Scottish Government has warned that as many as % of the population could become infected by the virus, with potentially % of this group requiring hospital treatment.But Ms Freeman said: ldquoNot all of those people will require hospital treatment at the same time.She said the Government was looking at capacity in the NHS and ldquowhat more we can do now in order to create additional headroom inside the health service.Consideration is also being given to how to increase capacity in areas of the NHS such as high oxygen therapy for patients, Mr Freeman said.Meetings are also taking place with local government leaders at Cosla to see what can be done to ensure patients do not have to stay in hospital longer than is needed because they are waiting for care arrangements.The Health Secretary said: ldquoThere is more than we need to do, we still have too many people not leaving at the point when the hospital has finished delivering clinical care.She spoke after figures published on Tuesday showed that the problem of delayed discharge had reached a new high.In January there were , patients whose discharge had been delayed, a rise of % from the same month a year before and the highest total since revised data definitions came into place in July .Ms Freeman has already told MSPs that emergency legislation could be introduced to support efforts to deal with the coronavirus.This could allow the Scottish Government to take ldquoextraordinary action, such as making vaccinations compulsory for healthcare workers.The emergency legislation, which is expected to be passed in Westminster later this month, will also waive some regulations to make it easier for former NHS Scotland staff toto their old jobs to ease the pressure on the health service.Ms Freeman told MSPs on Tuesday that the new powers reflected the ldquoextreme seriousness of the challenge we now face.: How can self-isolationaffect your rights and pay at work ldquoThe Bill will also enable us to require the mandatory vaccinations for health and social care workers ndash the flu vaccine ndashwe consider that the spread of the virus may continue into next yearrsquos flu season.ldquoGiven the projections of staff absences and the pressure on the NHS, we may wish to do all we can to protect both the workforce and patients.

title: joanna-cherry-mhairi-black-clash-chaotic-snp-metting
story: The Edinburgh South West MP, who has put herself forward to contest the Edinburgh Central Holyrood seat next year, clashed with Mhairi Black at a party meeting in Westminster, according to reports.The two MPs rowed over the fallout of a controversial school visit by drag-act, Flowjob ndash an event which Ms Black also attended in her constituency.Ms Black is said to have confronted her SNP colleague for not coming to her defence when she was subject to criticism for the incident at Glencoats Primary in Paisley last month.:Council apologises after FlowJob drag act invited to speak at primary schoolAccording to the Scottish Daily Mail, an MP source said: ldquoIt was a blazing row and angry words were exchanged.ldquoThings just hit boiling point in the meeting. It has been bubbling away for some time, but a massive row broke out. Nobody knew where to look ndash it was chaotic.It is also thought that at the meeting, Ms Black claimed she had offered to meet with Ms Cherry to clear up any dferences over the Scottish Governmentrsquos bid for gender self identication without a medical diagnosis, with the duo on opposite ends of the argument - but Ms Cherry had turned down the olive branch.Reports suggest that Ms Black accused Ms Cherry of ldquotrolling her on Twitter and blocked her from seeing her tweets. A source close to Ms Cherry denied this was the case.:Joanna Cherry: I dont want to replace Nicola. I want to get to know herYesterday it was revealed by leaked Whatsapp messages that Ms Cherry has told her SNP Westminster colleagues that publicly endorsing a candidate in the Edinburgh Central selection contest would be against party rules.But Alison Thewliss, the SNPrsquos treasury spokeswoman in Westminster, questioned this interpretation ndash saying it only applied to members of the partyrsquos ruling National Executive.:Joanna Cherry moves to stop SNP MPs endorsing candidates in selection battleA row has erupted after former SNP Westminster leader Angus Robertson announced his intention to seek election for Ruth Davidsonrsquos seat ndash with the former Scottish Tory leader to stand down at next yearrsquos election.Mr Robertsonrsquos move prompted Ms Cherry to throw her hat into the ring, and she has stated she would resign as an MPshe wins election to Holyrood.Ms Cherry has now moved to clear the air, by saying: ldquoIrsquom not in the business of leaking confidential messages or other dirty tricks.

title: labour-deputy-candidate-ian-murray-pledges-equality-women-party-leadership-team
story: Ian Murray has announced a plan to introduce a permanent co-deputy position, which must be filled by a woman, should his bid for deputy leadership succeed.The Edinburgh South MP also wants the UK and Scottish parliaments to introduce proxy voting and locums during maternity leave for politicians.It comes after Stella Creasy became the first MP to bring in a locum to stand in her place when she had a baby last year, handling constituency work and campaigns.Murray also stated that Holyrood should be "more flexible", and backed job-sharing roles, such as the idea put forward by Jackie Baillie MSP and Pauline McNeill MSP to share the role of Scottish Labour deputy leader, which was rejected by the party.Several female MSPs have recently stated they will not be standing in next years Holyrood elections, citing dfamily constraints and suggested introducing video conferencing for committees and electronic oting to allow easier remote working.He said: "We should always be proud of Labourrsquos record in achieving greater gender equality - both within our party and in society when we were in government. But there is so much more to do.ldquoThis starts with reforming our own party, which is why I am determined there should always be at least one woman in our leadership team.ldquoToo often when we talk about gender equality we ask what more can be done to support women to break through - rather than do the harder of work of seeking to change the system. I want to change the system.ldquoPublic service is something to be championed, but we cannot hope to encourage more people to choose it as a career unless we remove institutional barriers."

title: scottish-government-staff-offered-support-ahead-alex-salmond-trial
story: Civil servants were told ldquoguidance about the range of support available is on offer for anyone who has ldquoconcerns about the impact of the proceedings on their work or their wellbeing.Mr Salmond, , is due to go on trial next week after being charged with multiple sex offences including attempted rape.The former first minister denies all the allegations, which are claimed to have takenplace between June  and November  and relate to  women.The Scottish Government email, first reported by the Scottish Sun, told staff media coverage was ldquolikely to be extensive.It said: ldquoThe Scottish Government cannot comment on live criminal proceedings.ldquoColleagues are also reminded of their responsibilities under the Civil Service Code and social media guidance which they are required to exercise at all times.ldquoAs an organisation and as iniduals we must not do anything which might risk causing prejudice to the criminal proceedings.ldquoThe sensible course of action for members of staff is to make no comment about this case and, in particular, this includes on social media in either a professional or a personal capacity.Mr Salmond is accused of one count of attempted rape, one of sexual assault with intent to rape,  of sexual assault and two of indecent assault.His trial is expected to last around four weeks.

title: turn-rock-legends-genesis-play-scotland-reunion-tour
story: The Last Domino  Tour  starts in Dublin on November  and finishes at the Glasgow SSE Hydro on December .ldquoTherersquos a Genesis sound which is still there, said guitarist Mike Rutherford. ldquoI missed it, itrsquos nice to play it again.The reunion will see Phil Collins, Tony Banks and Mike Rutherford tour for the first time in  years.Their last live out was the globe-trotting, sell-out Turn It On Again: The Tour in .They will be joined on stage by Phil Collins -year-old son Nic on drums, and the bands long time guitar and bass player Daryl Stuermer.ldquoHe [Nic] plays like me and he kind of has the same attitude as me, said Collins. ldquoSo that was a good starter.Asked about the songs that the could play, Collins said: ldquoThere are songs you feel you have to play because the audience would feel cheatedyou didnrsquot, then itrsquos a question of putting the rest of the stuff together from songs we havenrsquot played for a long time.Genesis are one of the worldrsquos biggest selling and most successful bands of all time. They have sold an estimated  million albums and have played to sold-out stadiums and arenas all over the world for decades.The evolution of Genesis is unique, their sound developed and progressed throughout their career and with multiple line-up alterations in the early years, the classic line-up of Tony Banks, Phil Collins and Mike Rutherford took shape in .And Then There Were Threewas the first album the band released as a three-piece and spawned the single Follow You Follow Me which was their first UK top ten and US top  single and proved to be the start of huge commercial global success.The albums Duke , Abacab , Genesis , Invisible Touchand We Canrsquot Dancersquo followed for the trio, alongside almost constant global stadium tours cementing the band as one of the most successful of all time.It is estimated that Genesis have sold between  and m albums worldwide. In , they were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Their last album was Calling All Stations, released in .Tickets are to go ongeneral sale at am on Friday, March  from www.LiveNation and www.ticketmaster.

title: edinburgh-council-set-lease-biggest-hotel-city-prop-eiccs-finances
story: The Edinburgh International Conference Centrewants to take on a -bedroom hotel as part of a proposed development at a gap site near Haymarket station, which has remained empty for more than  years.The venture will also include a catering college, thought to be the first of its kind in the UK - in a partnership with Edinburhg College.Councillors will make a final decision on sub-leasing the building on March  - despite concerns by some that the impact of tourism should be curbed.The EICC needs a way of generating more income, with a council insider warning that the hotel ldquowill be their main income stream while ldquoconferencing will be reduced to a sideline.A hotelindustry source suggested the council venture could have an impact on the private sector.They said: ldquoThe council getting behind what will be the biggest hotel in the city is not particularly helpful to other hotel operators.ldquoI understand the challenges the EICC is faced with, but the hotel industry is finding things dficult too and its likely to get worse with Brexit.:Official Scottish visitor guide warns eco-tourists not to visit Edinburgh CastleThe council, which owns the EICC as an arms- company, has been asked to intervene amid a warning from the conference centre that a funding gap will need to be plugged in the coming years.A report to be considered by the City of Edinburgh Councilrsquos finance and resources committee on Thursday, will ask for politicians to endorse leasing the hotel and sub-leasing the venture to the EICC, who will ldquooperate the hotel under a franchise agreement with an international hotel brand.Council officials say that ldquothe profits from the hotel will be used to fund the required capital investment in the conference centre while the authority ldquowill not take on any risk associated with the construction of the hotel.The conference centre estimates that up to the end of , ldquosignicant capital expenditure will be needed but that the companyrsquos ldquosurpluses are not forecast to be sufficient to meet this expenditure.In the spring of , Quartermile Developments Limited, which is developing the Haymarket gap site, approached the council with the leaseholder option.A source close to the EICC said the catering school would help ldquoalleviate a skills shortage in the industry and would be ldquopioneering for the UK.The EICC has had to turn away events of up to , people due to their being no suitable accommodation for delegates to use.:Edinburgh tourism businesses warn of public backlash against industryIf approved, the majority of the  bedrooms would cater for business tourism.Council finance spokesperson Alasdair Rankin said: ldquoItrsquos clear that this project could offer signicant employment and training opportunities for local people, as well as forming an important part of the overall regeneration of the Haymarket gap site and helping to ensure the continued success of the EICC going forward, with no expected call on council budgets.ldquoA final decision on whether or not to proceed with this will be made by all councillors on  March.

title: gridlock-m8-pedestrian-resuscitated-carriageway
story: The motorway is gridlocked in both directions as emergency services are said to be trying to resuscitate the pedestrian on a carriageway near Junction  at Kinning Park.One onlooker saw five cars that had stopped in the vicinity.Traffic Scotland said traffic in both directors was affected."Traffic is getting past but its very slow on approach," said the agency."It looks like someone has been struck on the carriage, nearthe junction between M and M," said a police source. "There is an ongoing incident there."

title: two-virus-cases-scotland-uk-numbers-jump-87
story: The number of people who have tested positive for the virus rose to , including two new Scottish cases in Grampian and Ayrshire.One of the patients had recently ed from northern Italy and the second had contracted it from contact with another infected person, though authorities confirmed that this was not the Tayside case confirmed on Sunday.It brings the Scottish total to three. The First Minister said there could be ldquomany more in the days ahead.Speaking during a visit to an NHS  centre at the Golden Jubilee National Hospital in Clydebank, West Dunbartonshire, she said: ldquoThe reassurance for the public is that all appropriate steps are being taken.As part of the efforts to contain the virus, Ms Sturgeon said contact tracing was being carried out for the two new patients to ldquoidenty all the people they have been in close contact with for follow-up testing.While the ScottishGovernment has predicted that as many as  per cent of Scots could be struck by the virus, the First Minister said this was the ldquoworst-case scenario.She said: ldquoPeople right now are hearing big numbers, they are scary numbers and it is important we continue to put these in context. These are worst-case scenarios.ldquoWhy do we have worstcase scenarios  So we are properly planning for whatever we might be facing in this. But those worst-case scenarios are not a forecast of what will necessarily come to pass.Ms Sturgeon added: ldquoIt is also the case that whatever the number of people who might end up getting coronavirus might be, the vast majority will have mild symptoms, it will be like a cold or a mild case of flu. ldquoIt will be a smaller number who develop complications and need hospitalisation and that happens with seasonal flu every year.ldquoIt is also the case thatyou are hearing big numbers that is not about people all being affected at the one time, as with flu these things happen over a period of time.Ms Sturgeon said the ldquomost important thing the public can do is to wash their hands regularly.The Scottish Government said on Monday that a ldquoreasonable worst-case scenario could see  to % of the population contract Covid-, the name for the new strain of coronavirus.On the basis of current World Health Organisation data, which shows that around five per cent of people with the virus become critically ill ndash half of them fatally ndash that would equate to around , people being hospitalised in Scotland and more than , deaths.However, Professor Hugh Pennington, one of Scotlandrsquos leading infections experts, told The Herald that this was ldquonot a realistic estimate.Mr Pennington, emeritus professor of bacteriology at Aberdeen University, said the predictions were based on a scenario of widespread human-to-human transmission where ldquowe just let the virus run without any attempt to contain it.ldquoIt means that everything that could go wrong does go wrong, with absolutely no containment measures in place, he said.A dedicated NHS  helpline set up to manage coronavirus received nearly a thousand calls in the first  hours after Scotlandrsquos first case was confirmed on Sunday night.NHS  director of service delivery Steph Philips said: ldquoOver the last  days we have received more than , calls on coronavirus to our helpline and those numbers are increasing.Anyone worried about symptoms or possible exposure to the virus can call the helpline on   .Meanwhile, Health Secretary Jeane Freeman said the Scottish Government is looking at ldquowhat more we can do now in order to create additional headroom inside the health service.Consideration is also being given to how to free up more hospital beds and increase capacity in areas of the NHS such as high oxygen therapy, she said. Ventilation in intensive care and high-dependency units will be the main treatment for the most seriously ill. Frail elderly and people with diabetes, high blood pressure, and heart or lung problems are most at risk.Meanwhile, residents at a sheltered housing complex in Kilmarnock, East Ayrshire, were advised to stay in their homes ldquoas a precaution after a suspected case of coronavirus.Chris Milburn, customer services director for site manager Hanover Scotland, said: ldquoOn Tuesday, a resident at one of our developments in Ayrshire who had recently ed from south-east Asia reported feeling unwell.ldquoBecause the well-being of our residents and staff is our prime concern, our site manager immediately contacted the NHS and the resident was taken to hospital for tests.In Glasgow, a -year-old shopper was spotted wearing a protective face mask and gloves ndash despite official guidance that it does not prevent infection, but can help reduce onward spread in people who have already developed a cough.The man, Frank, said: ldquoIt is only a matter of time before itrsquos in Glasgow. ldquoSome people tell me Irsquom worrying about nothing and the mask wonrsquot do any good, but every little helps.It came as the UK recorded its biggest day-on-day increase in coronavirus cases, up  to .Three of the new cases recorded in England were passed on in the UK, raising fears that community transmission is escalating.Englandrsquos chief medical officer, Professor Chris Whitty, said: ldquoAt this point in time we think it is likely, not definite, that we will move into onward transmission and an epidemic here in the UK.He added that a very large epidemic, ldquowill put very high pressure on the NHS, and there could be ldquoseveral weeks which could be very dficult for the NHS and wider society.

title: coronavirus-italy-closes-schools-universities
story: The shutdown came after the death toll from the virus more than doubled in less than  hours, going from  on Monday to  yesterday.Cinemas and theatres will also be closed and Italians have been told to avoid hugging, kissing or shaking hands with each other.Italy has now recorded more deaths than either Iran or South Korea, and is second only to China.The victims included a -year-old with an existing chronic health condition ndash the youngest person to die from the outbreak in Italy so far ndash and a -year-old doctor who was not known to have any health problems.The Covid- strain has swept through Italy in the past two weeks, leading to flights being cancelled, towns quarantined and sporting fixtures and fashion shows called off.Vinitaly, one of the worldrsquos largest wine fairs held annually in the northern Italian city of Verona, was due to take place in April but has been postponed until June.At the last count, the World Health Organisationsaid there were , known cases of virus in Italy.Only China and South Korea have recorded more.Italian authorities have already cordoned off nearly a dozen so-called ldquored zones in the wealthy north of the country, including towns in Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, and Lombardy, where nearly two-thirds of cases have occurred.Inhabitants are blocked inside the affected towns and police are preventing any outsiders from entering.Plans are now under way for a possible new lockdown zone around the city of Bergamo, northeast of Milan, in a bid to stem a sharp rise in infections there.Among the new cases there were two magistrates who worked in Milanrsquos courtroom and a newborn baby in Bergamo.It was not clear how the child contracted the virus. Professor Massimo Galli, the director of infectious diseases at Sacco hospital in Milan, said Italyrsquos comparatively high elderly population could have left it more vulnerable to the virus.Italy has the highest le expectancy in Europe at  for men and  for women.Mr Galli said: ldquoItaly is a country of old people. The elderly with previous pathologies are notoriously numerous here.ldquoI think this could explain why we are seeing more serious cases of coronavirus here, which I repeat, in the vast majority of cases start mildly and cause few problems, especially in young people and certainly in children.ldquoOur le expectancy is among the highest in the world. But unfortunately, in a situation like this, old people are more at risk of a serious outcome.It came as the WHO warned that the latest data on Covid- indicates that it is more dangerous than seasonal influenza and likely to claim well over three times as many lives.Director-General Tedros Adhanom said: ldquoCovid- causes more severe disease than seasonal influenza. While many people globally have built up immunity to seasonal flu strains, Covid is a new virus to which no-one has immunity.ldquoThat means more people are susceptible to infection, and some will suffer severe disease.ldquoGlobally, about . per cent of reported Covid- cases have died. By comparison, seasonal flu generally kills far fewer than % of those infected.The lack of a vaccine was another major obstacle in the fight against Covi, said Mr Adhanom.Although numerous research efforts are under way worldwide, the clinical trials to ensure effectiveness and safety mean any immunisation programme is unlikely to be ready until  at the earliest.However, Mr Adhanom stressed that unlike influenza ldquocontainment is possible and that the evidence so far suggests that the virus does not spread as easily as flu.The WHO also revealed important developments in relation to how the virus presents.There have been suggestions that there could be large numbers of infected people in China without symptoms, potentially skewing scientistsrsquo efforts to count the incidence and estimate mortality rates.Mr Adhanom said this did not appear to be the case, but encouraged other nations to carry out mass surveillance.He said: ldquoEvidence from China is that only % of reported cases do not have symptoms, and most of those cases develop symptoms within two days. Some countries are looking for cases of Covid- using surveillance systems for influenza and other respiratory diseases.ldquoCountries such as China, Ghana, Singapore and where have found very few cases of Covid- among such samples ndash or no cases at all.ldquoThe only way to be sure is by looking for Covid- antibodies in large numbers of people, and several countries are now doing those studies. This will give us further insight into the extent of infection in populations over time.ldquoThe WHO has developed protocols on how these studies should be done, and we encourage all countries to do these studies and share their data.Worldwide, there have been more than , cases in  countries and some , deaths.The vast majority are still concentrated in China, but the spread there is continuing to slow.In the US, where there are now more than  confirmed cases, lawmakers were readying an  billion emergency bill to help fund efforts to contain the virus.It came as the number of cases in New York state rose to six. Among them were the family of a Manhattan lawyer who had tested positive for the coronavirus on Tuesday.The lawyerrsquos son is believed to have been studying at New Yorkrsquos Yeshiva University, which cancelled classes yesterday as a ldquoprecautionary step.Israelis ing from France, Germany, Spain, Austria and Switzerland have been ordered to selfisolate at home for  days, with non-residents potentially barred entry unless they agree to quarantine.Meanwhile, German airline Lufthansa says it is grounding  of its  aircraft in the wake of the crisis.Kristalina Georgieva, head of the International Monetary Fund, said epidemic posed a ldquoserious threat to global growth.

title: coronavirus-three-days-sick-pay-self-isolating-workers
story: Boris Johnson said that the rules will be changed, enabling workers to claim Statutory Sick Payfrom day one, instead of after four days.The announcement was made during Prime Ministerrsquos Questions yesterday, and applies to those who have the virus, as well as those who self-isolate.Mr Johnson said those who place themselves in quarantine are ldquohelping to protect all of us by slowing the spread of the virus.ldquoIf they stay at home andwe ask people to self isolate they may lose out financially, he told the Commons.He added: ldquo The Health Secretary will bring forward, as part of our emergency coronavirus legislation, measures to allow the payment of statutory sick pay from the very first day you are sick instead of four days under the current rules and I think thatrsquos the right way forward.ldquoNobody should be penalised for doing the right thing.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn welcomed the announcement but pressed the Prime Minister on whether it would apply to workers not entitled to statutory sick pay so they would not have to make the ldquoterrible choice between health and hardship.Mr Johnson said he was ldquovery much aware of issues faced by the selfemployed and those on zero-hours contracts, adding that ldquosome of them will be entitled to statutory sick pay, a great many.He said ministers were ldquourgently looking at the application process for social security payments.The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford asked Mr Johnson to ensure there would be no sanctions for people who claim benefitsthey miss appointments by being in isolation.He later confirmed that he would isolate himself in Parliament, should the need arise, to prevent the spread of the virus.Mr Blackford said: ldquoIf it comes to the point where there would be risks to the communities we serve, then bluntly I would probably take the decision to stay here because I certainly wouldnrsquot want to travel and expose people back in the constituency to it.ldquoI would probably self isolate myself in here .Marion Fellows, MP for Motherwell and Wishaw, welcomed Mr Johnsonrsquos pledge, but urged him to go further.She said: ldquoThe UK Government must extend the policy further to ensure that sick pay is set at an hourly rate and available for everyone for  weeks instead of .ldquoCurrent rules around SSP are not flexible enough to meet real-le needs, and fall far short of meeting a dignied standard of living ndash even with this new change. We must have a sick pay system fit for the st century which does not force people to choose between working while ill and hardship.ldquoDisability groups have been especially vocal in calling for an overhaul of the sick pay system. If the UK Government will not make these crucial changes then it should devolve the powers to Holyrood so it can.Meanwhile, Carol Monaghan, MP for Glasgow North West, suggested that parliamentarians themselves could act as ldquovectors for the spread of coronavirus.The SNP MP suggested bringing in conference call systems and other methods to allow Parliament to operate fully, without MPs having to travel excessively.She said: ldquoWe are all becoming increasingly concerned about Covid-.ldquoBut, every week,  of us come here from every part of the UK, spend several days operating in close proximity and meeting people from all over the world.ldquoWe thento our constituencies, potentially becoming the very vectors that wersquore trying to shut down.ldquoParliament must stay open. But what plans does the Prime Minister have to utilise systems such as conference calls and electronic voting to ensure we do not become part of the problem Mr Johnson replied: ldquoShersquos raising a very important point and the Chief Medical Officer and the Chief Scientic Adviser, together with the Health Secretary, will say a little bit more in the next couple of days about what wersquore going to do to delay the advance of coronavirus in Parliament and at other large gatherings.ldquoWersquore still at the containment stage ... when we come to the delay phase, shersquoll be hearing a lot more detail.

title: just-quarter-children-read-pleasure-every-day
story: The National Literacy Trustrsquos ninth Annual Literacy Survey questioned , children and young people aged nine to  in the UK in . Figures also showed that levels of enjoyment in reading were down.Just over halfof children and young people said they enjoyed reading either very much or quite a lot ndash the lowest level recorded by the Trust since .To combat the sharp decline, the charity behind World Book Day is encouraging people to help a nationwide effort to ldquoshare a million stories.The challenge involves reading or being read to for at least  minutes, with every person who hears the story counting towards the one million target.At the beginning of World Book Day more than , stories have already been ldquoshared as part of the campaign, which began on February  and runs until March .Events have been taking place across the country in locations including Middlesbrough Town Hall Theatre and Glasgow Royal Concert Hall as part of the Share A Million Stories campaign.Another event is taking place at the National Cycling Centre in Manchester today, which will be attended by author Cressida Cowell and TV presenter Dermot OrsquoLeary.The Duchess of Cornwall will also visit a London primary school today with author Anthony Horowitz, who created the Alex Rider childrenrsquos books.Cassie Chadderton, chief executive of World Book Day, said: ldquoYear on year, the evidence grows that World Book Day is having a positive impact on the reading behaviour of our children and young people.ldquoBy putting more books directly into the hands of children and young people and, at the same time, encouraging everyone, everywhere to get into the habit of sharing stories regularly, World Book Day is helping create readers for le.The revelation comes days after it was revealed that Scottish pupils have the joint greatest level of reading comprehension, alongside counterparts in Northern Ireland.However, despite primary and secondary pupils north of the Border, having the highest comprehension levels, on average they, are reading the least dficult books.The annual What Kids are Reading Report, written by Professor Keith Topping of the University of Dundee used data compiled by literacy and assessment provider Renaissance UK.The company examined the reading habits of ,, pupils, including , in Scotland.Harry Potter dominates favourite books ndash taking the top seven places for primary schools and is first choice for secondary pupils. Jeff Kinneyrsquos Diary of a Wimpy Kid series and David Walliamsrsquo Gangsta Granny and Billionaire Boy were amongst the most-read authors for both primary and secondary pupils.Mr Topping said: ldquoItrsquos great to see that Scottish pupils are at the top of the table in reading comprehension. Although important, instilling reading culture in schools isnrsquot just about dedicated reading time. Teachers and librarians should also encourage lively classroom discussion about fiction, with children sharing favourite authors and titles.ldquoThey should also be on hand to advise on books with appropriate challenge bespoke to the childrsquos interests. And of course, it is important to encourage children to read outside of school, so letting them take books home is crucial.

title: power-people-duke-agrees-major-land-transfer
story: Buccleuch ndash which comprises the business interests of the Buccleuch Family ndash has gted the land from its Borders Estate to Newcastleton  District Community Trust.The area encompasses a range of amenity sites in the village of Newcastleton and will enable the communityrsquos plans to utilise the land just a few miles from the Border with England.The agreement, after months of talks, has been warmly welcomed.Barbara Elborn, Secretary of Newcastleton  District Community Trust, said: ldquoThis is a delightful and historic moment for local people.ldquoWe have had very constructive discussions with Buccleuch about land use and ownership in the area and we look forward to progressing our plans.ldquoWe thank them and the Scottish Land Fund for their help and support to enable the community to move forward with its development plans.The land involved includes Polysport - a multisport pitch and fitness gym - a golf course and The Holm show fields.These sites have already been under long-term use by the community, which numbers around  people.Formal transfer of ownership will allow the trust to find increased community uses for the land and look at potential improvements of the facilities. In addition, a telecommunications mast site has been included to provide the community with an income.The agreement comes as Buccleuch continues negotiations for the sale of substantial areas of land to community groups, including Langholm Moor. Newcastleton  District Community Trust, meanwhile, is continuing to progress plans for a prospective purchase of land in the south of Scotland.Their application has been submitted to the Scottish Land Fund ahead of a decision due in May.Welcoming the latest development, Edward Morris, Buccleuch Estate manager, Borders Estate, said: ldquoWe are delighted to see this transfer of land taking place and we wish the community trust every success.Mr Morris added: ldquoWe have been in discussions for some time with groups around Newcastleton and Langholm regarding their aspirations for the local area and we are committed to helping community groups realise their aspirations where we can.The Buccleuch estates cover more than , acres of agricultural, forest and amenity land in Scotland, including more than  properties.Its Borders Estate was formed in September  following the merger of Eskdale  Liddesdale and Bowhill Estates.It includes , acres stretching from the Ettrick and Yarrow Valleys into Dumfries and Galloway, and to the Border with England.Buccleuch announced in May last year that it intended to sell a , acre landholding including Langholm Moor, following a review of land on its Borders Estate.The area, which was expected to sell for more than pound million, stretches from Auchenrivock in the south to Hartsgarth in the north, and is used for farming and forestry as well as an extensive moorland habitat.The transfer of amenity land from Bucceuch to Newcastleton  District Community Trust extends to  acres. Built following the land clearances in the s, when people were forced to move from Old Castleton village,Newcastleton has a vibrant cultural le and hosts a highly regarded traditional music festival every year.It has also emerged as an increasingly important location on the Scottish biking circuit, with nearby Newcastleton Forest home to one of the stanes mountain bike centres.

title: slow-steady-wins-race-new-look-politics
story: Tortoise, a new media  championing slow news, is holding a week-long series of discussions across the UK, called The Rules, and is looking for new ideas for the constitution.Last night some  people, of dferent ages and walks of le, gathered at a social enterprise in Glasgowrsquos Merchant City to share their ideas to make the political system more erse and inclusive.The event joins others in eight venues across the country from a community centre in Slindon, a newsroom in Grimsby, a museum in Cardf, a school in south London, a library in Newcastle, an arts centre in Belfast and in the heart of power, the House of Commons in London.Chaired by Liz Moseley, editor and partner of Tortoise, the evening of discussion was opened by Dr Lea Raible, a lecturer in public law at the University of Glasgow, who gave background information on the thrust of the discussion, which was whether the UK should move from an unwritten, codied constitution to a written constitution.One of Ms Moseleyrsquos suggestions was to create new categories for political representatives in addition to geographical representation.She said: ldquoYou live where you live. But there might be something , other than where you live, that you feel more connected to. Is that a way to structure an element of representation ldquoThese are all things we could, in theory, put back on the table.ldquoPerhaps therersquos an elected body over here thatrsquos to do with where I live and therersquos another elected or partially elected group over here thatrsquos partially to do with how old I am.ldquoThat might be a way to encourage people to engage dferently with the conversation.Another repeated suggestion of the session was the idea of citizenrsquos assemblies, closely linked to replacing a first past the post voting system with proportional representation.One participant, Corrina, said: ldquoI really like the idea of citizenrsquos assemblies. I think itrsquos really important that we get back down to the nuts and bolts and what people understand by politics in their daily lives.ldquoOur political system feels like a joke but, unfortunately, itrsquos a reality. It plays on that isiveness between people.ldquoThere needs to be a regulatory body that actually stops all the misinformation because how can people really be informed when therersquos so much rubbish thatrsquos put out there ldquoIn the end, people want to have decent housing, they want to have a good le for them and the community.ldquoSo we really need to speak to people whose voices are never heard. We have to speak to people who are, say, super racist.ldquoIt might be uncomfortable to have them in the room but because they have never been listened to itrsquos important to be in a space where we can start to understand each other.For participant Emma, who runs a charity, the situation must work to be more inclusive.She said: ldquoI think there is a more basic issue, politics, whether it is the mechanics of the system or the culture around it, it is not inclusive at all.ldquoI run a charity and we work with young people and adults with learning dficulties, young carers, people who are homeless. And they are the least likely to vote because the system is so complicated.ldquoIf you are a young person with a learning dficulty and you are trying to have influence there is just currently no system to support that.Student Alice told the group that she had not learned enough about the UK political system at school and felt let down by her experience of Modern Studies.She said: ldquoIt was more what they thought were things kids would find interesting rather than what we needed to know ndash we did a lot of laughing at Donald Trump.ldquoI have left school with a very small understanding of politics and Irsquom not happy about that.Tortoise aimed to set out the first inclusive membership model for news and now has , funded memberships.The organisation works with around  partners, including The Herald.There will be further Tortoise events throughout the year. To become involved email news@theherald

title: brian-beacom-return-genesis-boon-us-old-guys
story: Just as national morale is set to crash through the floor, these three auld fellas reveal they are prepared to play in ,-seater halls such as Londonrsquos O Arena and Glasgowrsquos SSE Hydro a drum stick in the eye to coronavirus!Prog rock, of course, was essentially British, which will appeal to the Remainers who want to rewind back to the days of musical expansionism and to Brexiteers who wish to happily wave goodbye to a musical legacy soon to be forgotten for good.Yes, the music of Genesis is pretentious and tedious. Mike Rutherford, Tony Banks, Phil Collins and Steve Hackettsold m records based largely on the support of teenage boys who couldnrsquot get a girlfriend and spent way too much time in their bedrooms, practising guitar solos on a fretless and reading Philip Roth novels.Genesis produced album tracks so long you could put one on the record player before going to bed and Banks and co would still be blasting away by breakfast.Now, I wasnrsquot a Genesis fan the idea of worshipping a vainglorious lead singer who wore a foxrsquos head angered me to the point of mounting a horse, donning a red jacket and yelling lsquoTally ho!rsquo at the top of my voice. Peter Gabriel had to be hunted down.But I was a fan of prog rock. I loved Yes and the Yes Album and a bit of Jethro and a lot of Emerson, Lake and Palmer. And why wouldnrsquot I Prog rock was unashamedly pretentious, elitist and to enjoy it was to mock the becircte noire of adolescents through the ages ndash duty, conformity ndash and parents such as your dad, who liked Jim Reeves.The likes of Yes and ELP, to the teenager in the s, were iconoclastic. These bands had the rampant disdain for traditional song structures ndash verse chorus . . . sometimes a middle eight ndash opting instead for long rambling jazz tunes which featured several key changes, dissembled melodies and use of vocal counterpoint. The likes of the wonderful Yes and Genesis paraded self-indulgent solos that stretched patience to the limit.Prog rock was, of course, a command for attention we boyscould relate to. It was the musical version of Lindsay Andersonrsquos film If, featuring middle-class boys from a toff school, olde England tradition mixed with rage. Indeed, the genesis of Genesis took place at Charterhouse College.Yes, there are those who will say Genesis are past it. Theyrsquoll say Phil Collins was once one of the worldrsquos greatest drummers but now he walks with a stick and can barely hold a pair of chop sticks. stage school kid.There are those who say Genesisrsquo reformation isnrsquot complete because Peter Gabriel wonrsquot be part of the line up but you could argue itrsquos  years since he appeared with his one-time chums on stage. Why not invite him along  No one could have countenanced a reformation of The Beatles without Lennon and McCartney, the Kinks without both Davies brothers.Sure, there are critics who will point out Collins and co donrsquot need the money. .But thatrsquos not the point. If we get to see the likes of Banks and co up there on stage we get a visual reminder that the riches of Croesus canrsquot protect from cellular degeneration nor frequency sensorineural hearing loss.We get to appreciate that these fellas might have beautul wives and lives but they still need something to do during the day. They still need a bit of attention. "I worked it out and weve only done two shows in the UK in the last  years, so we havent over-worked it, said Mike Rutherford.There you go. He knows itrsquos time to make an appearance. And have a laugh at the expense of all-too affluent babyboomers.This lot have turned musical rebellion into power, and squillions of cash. Now, theyrsquore recreating Nerdland. This is a Ted Talk with guitars for musical snobs.And theyrsquore out to prove old, privileged white men can still rip us off blind, and laugh in the faces of the little anoraky, self-absorbed boys we once were. What can be wrong with that

title: neil-mackay-radicalised-online-confession
story: The world needs to know about people like me.The internet has started to give me violent thoughts. Itrsquos true. Itrsquos even made me fantasise about committing an act of terrorism.This is the plot that my exposure to the internet and online radicalisation has fostered in my mind: I want to blow up the internet.I donrsquot mean lsquoblow up the internetrsquo in the way the kids means it, as in get loads of retweets or likes and blow it up. I mean actually blow it up. The real internet. With explosives.Boom. Gone. Cyber Guy Fawkes.But herersquos the problem: Irsquove no idea where the internet is. And then therersquos the fact that Irsquom a pretty lazy, middle-aged writer who finds it dficult to wire a plug let alone construct a bomb. I also donrsquot like violence. So my motivation and commitment may be defeated by my character and skill set.Just in case a secret policeman from the Prevent programme is reading this without a sense of irony, I donrsquot really want to blow up the internet ... personally.But I would like it gone. From the face of the planet. At least, in its current incarnation.If I could snap my fingers and make the internet disappear, Irsquod do it right now.This month marks the st birthday of the internet. In three decades itrsquos caused more harm, more quickly, to humanity than any other invention. I struggle to see an upside to its existence.Itrsquos made a world full of extremists. We may not be lunatics in our real lives but once we get online we self-radicalise. Black, white. Gay, straight. Left, right. Leave, Remain. Yes, No. Trans, cis. Everyone hates everyone .When we arenrsquot hiding behind anonymous social media accounts spouting hate, we become mawkish, sentimental hypocrites online. We bully and abuse some celebrity or royal one week, and then once wersquove broken and destroyed them we cry and tell everyone to lsquobe kindrsquo the next week.The greatest damage that the internet has done in its current incarnation is to destroy the belief that human beings are essentially good. Online wersquore generally bad and stupid.Wersquove given it total control over our lives. Itrsquos enslaved us psychologically. We tell the internet everything about ourselves - things we wouldnrsquot tell our partners or doctors. We let the internet listen to us, see us, study us, through smart devices and monitors. Then we allow corporations to monetise this information. Wersquore idiots.Itrsquos made us poorer. The internet came along and ate up jobs. It put people out of work. It destroyed our high streets and closed shops. Our economy has been continually, unnecessarily and negatively disrupted by the digital world. And at what gain to you or I  Are we happier, richer, safer  The internet proves progress is a myth.The jobs the internet has created are mostly precarious and low paid. Where once our parents and grandparents depended on a job for le, now our children struggle to keep their heads above water in the gig economy.We canrsquot just blame our terrible governments for this - governments are weak in the face of the internet. The internet is the new invisible guiding hand in world events, and governments are here today, gone tomorrow.The tech giants are like new East India Companies - theyrsquore as rich as small nations, wield power without accountability, flout their taxes, harvest us for data, cause electoral manipulation. Theyrsquore corporate vampires.The internet has changed us emotionally. Itrsquos locked us behind screens at the dinner table. Itrsquos transformed iPads into nannies. People chose their partners by swiping. Itrsquos turned extreme pornography into digital background static. It isolates and dehumanises us.Culturally, wersquore fading away. The internet offers up so much trash that therersquos no time or space for real art, real literature. Therersquos no time for real debate, real analysis. We skim headlines, we donrsquot read stories. Our attention spans are declining. Wersquore changing from a book culture to a screen culture.Fewer and fewer people pay for culture anymore. They want songs, films, TV, books and newspapers for free. If thatrsquos the case then who pays the songwriter, filmmaker, showrunner, writer or editor  Without financial reward, culture dies.Politically, the internet has fuelled populism, the alt-right, cancel culture, anti-semitism, conspiracies, the extreme lsquowokersquo totalitarianism of the left. Itrsquos carpet-bombed the centre ground.It can be changed, though. My rage against the internet is like blaming physics for the atom bomb. Itrsquos not the science thatrsquos wrong, itrsquos the way people have harnessed the science which is dangerous.The internet has the temerity to set itself up as an alternative to reality. You can go online and shop, fall in love, be political, and consume culture, just as you do in real le. Given thatrsquos the case, then treat the online world like the real world.Police it like the real world. I canrsquot walk down the street in a balaclava shouting rape threats. So online you should have to show your face and go by your real name, just as you do in the physical world.Sites like Facebook and Twitter are publishers. Except Facebook and Twitter arenrsquot subject to the same laws as the rest of the media. End that. Drag a few tech execs into court, the way you can bring a real world publisher into court, and things will change rapidly online.And tax the hell out of the internet. If you make a buck in Britain, then pay your fair share. Otherwise face being shut down, or prosecuted.Itrsquos really not too late to fix things. Victorian industrialists thought they could stuff children up chimneys with impunity until society said stop. The world of publishing was a demented free-for-all after the invention of the printing press until libel and defamation laws finally emerged and the crazies got silenced.Change can be made. It better be made. Otherwise, well, I might genuinely end up getting radicalised.Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year

title: mps-suggest-isolating-parliament-block-spread-covid-19-workers-get-three-days-sick-pay
story: Boris Johnson said that the rules will be changed, enabling wokrers to claim Statutory Sick Payfrom day one, instead of after four days.The announcement was made during Prime Ministers Questions yesterday, and applies to those who have the virus as well as those who self-isolate.Johnson said those who place themselves in quarantine are "helping to protect all of us by slowing the spread of the virus"."If they stay at home andwe ask people to self isolate they may lose out financially," he told the Commons.He added: " I can today announce that the Health Secretary will bring forward, as part of our emergency coronavirus legislation, measures to allow the payment of statutory sick pay from the very first day you are sick instead of four days under the current rules and I think thats the right way forward."Nobody should be penalised for doing the right thing."Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn welcomed the announcement but pressed the Prime Minister on whether it would apply to workers not entitled to statutory sick pay so they would not have to make the "terrible choice between health and hardship".Mr Johnson said he was "very much aware" of issues faced by the self-employed and those on zero-hours contracts, adding that "some of them will be entitled to statutory sick pay, a great many".He said ministers were "urgently looking" at the application process for social security payments.The SNPs Westminster leader Ian Blackford asked Johnson to ensure there would be no sanctions for people who claim benefitsthey miss appointments by being in isolation.Marion Fellows, MP for Motherwell and Wishaw said welcomed Johnstons SSP pledge, but urged him to go further.She said: "I am pleased that Statutory Sick Paywill now begin from the first day of a workerrsquos absence instead of after four but the UK government must extend the policy further to ensure that sick pay is set at an hourly rate and available for everyone for  weeks instead of .ldquoCurrent rules around SSP are not flexible enough to meet real le needs, and fall far short of meeting a dignied standard of living ndash even with this new change. We must have a sick pay system fit for the st century which does not force people to choose between working while ill and hardship.ldquoDisability groups have been especially vocal in calling for an overhaul of the sick pay system. Their concerns must be factored into the UK governmentrsquos response to their sick pay consultation.ldquoIf the UK government will not make these crucial changes then it should devolve the powers to Holyrood so it can ndash to meet peoplersquos needs in Scotland and ensure their standard of living is not disadvantaged by Coronavirus or any other illness that they have contracted through no fault of their own.Meanwhile Carol Monaghan, the MP for Glasgow North West, suggested that parliamentarians themselves could act as "vectors" for the spread of coronavirus.The SNP MP suggested bringing in conference call systems and other methods to allow parliament to operate fully, without MPs having to travel excessively.She said: "We are all becoming increasingly concerned about Covid-, the coronavirus."But, every week,  of us come here from every part of the UK, spend several days operating in close proximity and meeting people from all over the world."We thento our constituencies, potentially becoming the very vectors that were trying to shut down."Parliament must stay open. But what plans does the Prime Minister have to utilise systems such as conference calls and electronic voting to ensure we do not become part of the problem "Johnson replied: "Shes raising a very important point and the Chief Medical Officer and the Chief Scientic Adviser, together with the Health Secretary, will say a little bit more in the next couple of days about what were going to do to delay the advance of coronavirus in Parliament and at other large gatherings."Were still at the containment stage ... when we come to the delay phase, shell be hearing a lot more detail about what we propose to do with large gatherings in places such as Parliament."
